heading: lucent posts record profit
subheading: the telecom equipment behemoth tops wall street forecasts for the most recent quarter -- as it has every quarter since leaving the at&t fold three years ago. also: silicon graphics may be on the comeback trail.
author: wired news report
text: telecommunications equipment leader lucent technologies reported better-than-expected first-quarter profits on thursday, driven by improved profit margins and phone companies' strong demand for data and internet equipment. lucent (lu) also said it was optimistic about its prospects for its fiscal year ending in september, anticipating earnings to increase about 35 percent on revenue growth of about 20 percent.in the quarter ending december 1998, lucent's profits swelled to us$2.7 billion, or $2 a share, compared with $792 million, or 61 cents a share, a year ago. excluding one-time gains and charges, profits rose 26 percent to a record $1.41 billion or $1.05 a share.lucent, which last week agreed to buy data networking company ascend communications, has topped earnings expectations every quarter since it was spun off from at&t in 1996.thursday's results beat wall street expectations of $1.01 a share, according to first call, which tracks analysts' estimates. lucent's quarterly revenues grew almost 6 percent to $9.2 billion from $8.7 billion, as some revenue it had expected to record at the end of the first quarter was delayed into the second quarter.- - -recovery in progress: silicon graphics reported a $20 million loss in its most recent quarter, but it was less red ink than expected. the workstation maker saw the results as further progress in its year-long turnaround effort.the loss in the quarter ended 31 december, reported after the close of markets wednesday, come to 11 cents per share. in the same period of 1997, the company lost $31.5 million or 17 cents a diluted share. the first call consensus forecast was for a 19-cent loss.silicon graphics (sgi), which has seen its leadership position in computer design products erode in recent years, last week unveiled a line of workstations designed to win business back from the competition. the workstations cost a fraction the price of the older models but perform many of the same visualization and simulation functions that have made silicon graphics' machines popular among movie special effects teams and engineers.in an interview on wednesday, senior vice president bill kelly estimated the new machines would generate sales of close to $500 million in fiscal 1999. although kelly said it was too early to release initial sales data, he said the response to the new machines has been "extremely favorable around the world."reuters contributed to this report.
